description:
Cicer arietinum, commonly known as chickpea or garbanzo bean, is a species of legume that belongs to the family Fabaceae. It is an annual herbaceous plant that typically grows to a height of 20-60 cm.

The plant has a finely-branched, erect stem and compound leaves composed of 11-15 leaflets. The flowers are white, pink, or purple in color and are self-pollinating. The fruits are pods that contain 1-2 seeds, which are the edible part of the plant.

Chickpeas are a valuable source of protein, fiber, carbohydrates, and various vitamins and minerals, including folate, iron, and phosphorus. They are widely cultivated and consumed as a staple food in many parts of the world, particularly in the Middle East, the Indian subcontinent, and the Mediterranean region.

Cicer arietinum is an important crop for its nutritional value and has been an integral part of human diets for thousands of years. It is known for its versatility in culinary applications and is used in a variety of dishes, such as curries, soups, and salads.
